message: I had a bad dream the other night. I dreamed that I was sitting on an old wooden armchair in an apartment that I lived in on Marine Drive. It was a massive apartment. This was an apartment you would have to measure not in hundreds of square feet, but in thousands of square feet, perhaps even in acres. And as I sat on my old wooden armchair, the same armchair on which Jawaharlal Nehru had once panked Indira, I heard a loud noise. It was the kind of sound a house would make if a house could fart. I looked to my right and there was a huge crack on the wall. I heard the sound again and some cement dust fell on me. The ceiling was cracking now. I looked out through the window on my right and the building there collapsed. All around me, the cracks in the walls just grew. I looked through the inside door of the house and I found that half of bedroom 44 had collapsed. My old poster bed, on which Motilal Nehru's mother had given birth to Motilal, was half in the room and half suspended in space. Clearly the house was collapsing. One of the cracks in the wall nearest to me widened and became a hole. A sparrow thrust its head through that hole. It made chirrupy noises at me. This is a rent-controlled flat. I pay only twenty rupees a month to live here. I can never leave this flat. And the sparrow said, Damn this rent control!
